On Tue, 2003-04-08 at 16:05, javainsel wrote: 

> I just want to use Mock objects for the database. The test data must 
> be coming
> from the test classes and not be inside the database. So we need 
> Mock objects
> I think. But I don't know how to create them since I still don't 
> know how
> our framework works inside and how Mock objects are used.
> 
> Now you think it is not necessary that our framework supports Mock 
> objects?

Do you know what types of result sets you expect from the database
layer?  If so, mock out your database connection logic (the object that
would return you a java.sql.ResultSet) and have it return mock result
sets from which you can create your business objects.  Any IDE worth its
salt should be able to stub the 'million and one' methods in ResultSet
-- then you simply implement the ones you want.  How you create those
MockResultSet's is another story.

We have some code for doing it, but I don't know if I can release it to
the public (I am a contractor on this project).  If so, I will do it
soon, if not I will see if I have time to mock one up and share it with
the group (perhaps Junit-Addons?).  The basic idea we have here for
creating our MockResultSet's is to create them with column names and
values.  They can be single-row or multi-row sets.  Basically, we
implemented the navigation methods that we needed (i.e. next()) and the
getXYZ() methods that we needed (i.e. getString(...), getInt(...),
getLong(...), getDate(...)).

Hope that helps.
=jason
